ratings.comment: Henry is a very nice man, caring, and wants to ensure that students succeed in his class. He is very flexible regarding due dates. Despite his good qualities, Henry is very disorganized and lacks clarity in many of his class-wide emails regarding important class information. For me, the way he taught the material was not effective for me.

Prof Mendoza was kind & genuinely seemed like he wanted you to succeed. However, this class was the absolute worst. I took AP Stats which is probably the only reason I did semi-decent. It requires you to code all your work which to be difficult and made the class 100x harder. Take a different stats class.

The worst professor I have had in my life. There was no clear way to study for this class because of the absolutely useless lectures that were just a monotone reading of notes with zero extra explanations. Even my TA had no clue what to study or how to study for any of the tests because they had poor communication with Henry the entire semester.
He genuinely wants students to get an A and if you reach out to him hell go out of his way to help you. Class is graded so at least 25% of students get an A

I would rather have Tunnel Bob bludgeon me in the head with a hot steam pipe than interact even once with Henry. In fact, this would probably benefit me since I would likely lose all memories of this atrocious class.

Literally, I don't understand how Prof is at a school such as Madison. Never responds to emails, or student concerns. Never uploaded class materials on time. Lectures were a miserable waste of time, just skim them and it would be the most valuable thing. Annihilated the class with a brutally hard 2nd exam. 10/10 do not take, my dog teaches better.

The homework assignments focused more on coding than the actual stats concepts and took several hours to complete; copying lecture codes for homework is the only reason I passed. Professor avoided questions several times after being asked for clarification; he was not helpful. I still don't understand most things that this class covered. Nightmare!

Professor Mendoza is an excellent teacher. He fully takes time out of his day to make sure each student fully understands and takes in the material. He is very understanding about unforseen circumstances . He helps all of his students and really wants them to succeed.

The only reason I have a B in this class is because he gives an obnoxious amount of homework that takes 4 ish hours to do and this does not include lecture, the weekly quizes, or discussion. I failed all the exams because his lectures were not helpful. He posted the final 4 hours late and expected us to understand the errors he made on it.

Literally the worst professor/teacher I have ever encountered in my academic career. He did not upload the final exam at the specified time, hindering many students' ability to even take the exam, grades very harshly, and is a horrible instructor of material. Nothing made sense with what he taught, and I genuinely still do not know the material.

He has a heavy accent which can be challenging to understand personally absolutely despise statistics and struggled majorly during this class and I know I am not the only one Make sure you pay attention from the very beginning or you will struggle later in the semester Need extra points? Just email him he is very understanding&wants you to pass

Professor Mendoza Rivera is a solid choice and the hate towards him is not called for. Given my interactions in office hours and general class communications, he seems like a really nice professor who cares about his students. All exams were open note with lots of time. Homework sets are useful, especially if you get help during office hours.

Easily the worst professor I've had. Does not respect his students in his communications, nor does he explain well in his lectures. He expects you to intuitively understand messy coding. Someone said you can just copy-paste the code and get a perfect score, but that doesn't work on the exams. Don't expect help in this class, because there is none.

A recent exam went badly, hence all the 1/5 reviews. The average grade in the class is an 85 now, and over 30 percent of students end up with A's. The class only takes 5-6 hours a week; which is not bad for 4 credits. You can get a perfect score by copying lecture code. "Not helpful" reviews mean "I cant bully him into giving me a curve".

He completely disregards concerns of his students. His lectures consist of him reading and highlighting slides that are filled with typos. The homework assignments take about 4 hours every week, if not more. The average of one of the exams was 72%, 15% below the average of the first exam, but he won't curve. The worst professor I've had at Madison.

The only reason I have an A in this course is because I have taken AP Statistics before. Even with my background knowledge, this class is a lot of work. You essentially have to teach yourself the material because the professor's lectures don't really help, and on top of that, you have to learn how to use R(a statistical programming language).

You will never learn in this class, but figure out how to do decent on homework to get by week to week. Henry doesn't actually teach, but reads vague information from poorly constructed slides in .html format. Get ready to code, and learn for yourself. You will despise this class, TA's and professor. Never responds to questions. Ever. DO NOT TAKE

Professor Rivera doesn't actually teach. His lectures consist of him highlighting things and putting them into R, a program you will learn to hate because you'll never be taught how to use it. I once went to his office hours to ask a specific question about something from lecture and was told you don't pay attention to lecture you won't get an A.

This professor clearly doesn't care about teaching or his students. A hard to understand accent mixed with mumbling and low quality audio on lectures make him impossible to understand. In addition to this, his lectures consist of him highlighting text and reading it off the page! No exam information is given prior to the midterm.
